newsitem.title: GERMANY: Jungheinrich sees profit by year-end, sheds jobs.
newsitem.headline: Jungheinrich sees profit by year-end, sheds jobs.

text.p: German forklift truck manufacturer Jungheinrich said on Friday it expected to return to profit by the end of 1996 after making a loss of 7.2 million marks ($4.7 million) in the first six months.

The company also announced it planned to shed 260 jobs in its factory in Norderstedt, northern Germany, in a bid to save costs totalling 40 million marks by end-1997. Jungheinrich employed about 8,800 people at the end of 1995.
Management board chairman Hans-Peter Schmohl said 1996 earnings depended on how the market developed in the coming months.
Group sales adjusted for exchange rate movements rose by six percent to about 1.5 billion marks in the first seven months of 1996, Schmohl told a news conference.
Jungheinrich attributed its first-half loss to restructuring costs and falling demand. In 1995, the company made a group net profit of 47.3 million marks on sales of 2.3 billion.
